clinical_study.brief_title: Study to Determine the Efficacy and Safety of a Novel Nicotine Replacement Therapy
clinical_study.official_title: A Multicenter, Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled, Parallel Group Study Using a Naturalistic Clinical Model to Measure the Efficacy and Safety of a Novel Nicotine Replacement Therapy in Smokers Motivated to Quit

lead_sponsor.agency: McNeil Consumer Healthcare Division of McNEIL-PPC, Inc.

clinical_study.source: Johnson & Johnson Consumer and Personal Products Worldwide

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to assess the efficacy and safety of a novel nicotine product for continuous abstinence from smoking. Efficacy of product will be evaluated by assessments of self-reported abstinence, verified by exhaled carbon monoxide (CO) levels.

primary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With Continuous Smoking Abstinence From Week 2 to Week 6
primary_outcome.description: Percentage of participants with carbon monoxide (CO)-verified self-report of continuous abstinence from smoking

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With Continuous Smoking Abstinence From Week 2 to Week 12
secondary_outcome.description: Percentage of participants with carbon monoxide (CO)-verified self-report of continuous abstinence from smoking

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage Distribution of the Rating of Desire/Urge to Smoke on a Categorical Scale at Week 1
secondary_outcome.description: Participants were asked if during the last 24 hours they experienced the desire/urge to smoke on a 5-grade categorical scale of 0 - 4 (where 0=not at all and 4=extremely so).

secondary_outcome.measure: Aggregated Withdrawal Score at Week 1
secondary_outcome.description: Participants were asked if during the last 24 hours they experienced each of 7 withdrawal symptoms on a 5-grade categorical scale of 0 - 4 (where 0=not at all and 4=extremely so). The aggregated withdrawal symptom score was the sum of the scores of the 7 withdrawal symptoms (irritability-frustration-anger, restlessness, difficulty concentrating, anxiety, dysphoric or depressed mood, insomnia, and increased appetite). The total scores are reported with a minimum possible score of 0 and a maximum possible score of 28.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage Distribution of the Participant Score for Overall Product Rating at Week 1
secondary_outcome.description: Participants were asked to rate the investigational product on a 10-point scale of 1 - 10 (where 1=very poor and 10=excellent).

secondary_outcome.description: Participants were asked to rate the investigational product on a 10-point scale of 1 - 10 (where 1=very poor and 10=excellent).

secondary_outcome.description: Participants were asked to rate the investigational product on a 10-point scale of 1 - 10 (where 1=very poor and 10=excellent).

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage Distribution of the Participant Score for Product Effectiveness in Dealing With Desire/Urge to Smoke at Week 1
secondary_outcome.description: Participants were asked to rate the product in its effectiveness for dealing with desire/urge to smoke on a 5-point scale of 1 - 5 (where 1=not all effective and 5=extremely effective).

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage Distribution of the Participant Score for Product Effectiveness in Dealing With Desire/Urge to Smoke at Week 6
secondary_outcome.description: Participants were asked to rate the product in its effectiveness for dealing with desire/urge to smoke on a 5-point scale of 1 - 5 (where 1=not all effective and 5=extremely effective).

secondary_outcome.description: Participants were asked to rate the product in its effectiveness for dealing with desire/urge to smoke on a 5-point scale of 1 - 5 (where 1=not all effective and 5=extremely effective).

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage Distribution of the Participant Score for Speed of Action of the Product at Week 1

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With New or Worsened Conditions in Lips/Labial Mucosa at Week 6 or When Withdrawn From Study
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Week 6 or when withdrawn from study
secondary_outcome.description: Visual mouth inspection (VMI) performed at the site or local dental office by a licensed dentist or an examiner such as a dental hygienist with documented training in oral clinical exams. Extraoral and intraoral tissues were examined. Abnormalities were recorded; it was determined if abnormalities were new or had worsened since baseline VMI findings.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
Subjects must be males or females 18-85 years of age who currently smoke cigarettes daily and are willing to stop smoking
Exclusion Criteria:
History of cardiovascular disease, stomach ulcer or diabetes unless physician's written approval is obtained.
Use of other forms of tobacco/nicotine containing products other than cigarettes within 30 days before baseline visit.
Use of nicotine replacement therapies or other smoking cessation medicines/non-drug therapies within 30 days before the baseline visit.
Pregnancy or intending to become pregnant.
Hypersensitivity to the product, history of alcohol or substance abuse.

outcome.title: Percentage of Participants With Continuous Smoking Abstinence From Week 2 to Week 6
outcome.description: Percentage of participants with carbon monoxide (CO)-verified self-report of continuous abstinence from smoking
outcome.population: Analysis was based on the Full Analysis Set which included all randomized participants.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Placebo capsaicin mouth spray, 0 mg nicotine/dose, intraorally per label directions

measure.title: Percentage of Participants With Continuous Smoking Abstinence From Week 2 to Week 6
measure.description: Percentage of participants with carbon monoxide (CO)-verified self-report of continuous abstinence from smoking
measure.population: Analysis was based on the Full Analysis Set which included all randomized participants.

analysis.groups_desc: The null hypothesis was no difference in continuous smoking abstinence rates between treatments. The alternative hypothesis was a difference in continuous smoking abstinence rates between treatments.
analysis.method_desc: Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel test stratified by study site and number of cigarettes smoked per day at baseline (<20 per day vs ≥20 per day).

outcome.title: Aggregated Withdrawal Score at Week 1
outcome.description: Participants were asked if during the last 24 hours they experienced each of 7 withdrawal symptoms on a 5-grade categorical scale of 0 - 4 (where 0=not at all and 4=extremely so). The aggregated withdrawal symptom score was the sum of the scores of the 7 withdrawal symptoms (irritability-frustration-anger, restlessness, difficulty concentrating, anxiety, dysphoric or depressed mood, insomnia, and increased appetite). The total scores are reported with a minimum possible score of 0 and a maximum possible score of 28.
outcome.population: Analysis was based on randomized participants verified abstinent from smoking since the last visit.

measure.title: Aggregated Withdrawal Score at Week 1
measure.description: Participants were asked if during the last 24 hours they experienced each of 7 withdrawal symptoms on a 5-grade categorical scale of 0 - 4 (where 0=not at all and 4=extremely so). The aggregated withdrawal symptom score was the sum of the scores of the 7 withdrawal symptoms (irritability-frustration-anger, restlessness, difficulty concentrating, anxiety, dysphoric or depressed mood, insomnia, and increased appetite). The total scores are reported with a minimum possible score of 0 and a maximum possible score of 28.
measure.population: Analysis was based on randomized participants verified abstinent from smoking since the last visit.

analysis.groups_desc: The null hypothesis was no difference in distribution of aggregated withdrawal scores between treatments. The alternative hypothesis was a difference in distribution of aggregated withdrawal scores between treatments.

outcome.title: Percentage of Participants With New or Worsened Conditions in Lips/Labial Mucosa at Week 6 or When Withdrawn From Study
outcome.description: Visual mouth inspection (VMI) performed at the site or local dental office by a licensed dentist or an examiner such as a dental hygienist with documented training in oral clinical exams. Extraoral and intraoral tissues were examined. Abnormalities were recorded; it was determined if abnormalities were new or had worsened since baseline VMI findings.
outcome.time_frame: Week 6 or when withdrawn from study
outcome.population: Analysis was based on the Safety Analysis Set which included all randomized participants who received study treatment.

measure.population: Analysis was based on the Safety Analysis Set which included all randomized participants who received study treatment.

analysis.groups_desc: The null hypothesis was no difference in mean change from baseline in body weight between treatments. The alternative hypothesis was a difference in mean change from baseline in body weight between treatments.
analysis.method_desc: Treatment, baseline smoking category, study site, and baseline weight were factors.
analysis.estimate_desc: Least Squares Mean Difference = Nicotine - Placebo

reported_events.time_frame: Through 26-week end-of-study visit or through early termination visit; + up to 30 days for unresolved adverse events; +30 days for serious adverse events
reported_events.desc: AEs were systematically collected during the study. AEs that were unresolved upon completion or termination from the study were followed for up to 30 calendar days until the event or its sequelae resolved or stabilized. Serious AEs were collected through 30 calendar days after the participant’s last study visit.

category.title: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: Prior to submission for publication, PI was to provide sponsor with ≥ 60 days for publication review. No publication that included sponsor confidential information was to be submitted without sponsor’s consent. If requested, the PI was to withhold publication for up to 60 additional days to allow for patent application filing. First publication of study results was to be a joint, multicenter publication; if not submitted within 6 months after end of study, the PI may publish the site results.
